results.title: Nadja
results.creator_credit: Michael Almereyda, Amy Hobby, Mary Sweeney and Kino Link Company
results.brief_description: Revisiting the vampire legend director/writer Michael Almereyda creates a modern day setting for several sexy undead creatures of the night. Elina Lowensohn plays the title role - a New York based vampire who is celebrating the demise of her father, and is hoping that her new life will encompass the attractive Lucy. Unfortunately Lucy is married to the nephew of a vampire hunter who is hell-bent on conquering Nadja. Aesthetically the film is an alluring mix of 35 mm footage and black-and-white, low-budget Pixelvision video. As an art film, the form is impressive but the narrative wanes at key moments, leaving an overall sense of a film that wavers inconsistently between a surrealist Lynchian vision and the deadpan humour of a Hal Hartley.

results.title: Hidden agenda
results.creator_credit: Ken Loach, Eric Fellner and Hemdale Film Corporation
results.brief_description: American lawyer Paul Sullivan (Brad Dourif), is working in Northern Ireland as part of a group similar to Amnesty International, when he is assassinated by police who claimed that he failed to stop at a road block and was in the company of a suspected terrorist. His fiancee and fellow activist Ingrid Jessner (Frances McDormand) is left shattered. She has a glimmer of hope that justice will prevail after the arrival of British policeman Paul Kerrigan (Brian Cox) who has been sent to investigate the circumstances surrounding the death, and the actions of the three men implicated in the deaths: members of the undercover anti terrorist squad, the SSU (Special Support Unit). Kerrigan is initially fearless in his investigation, refusing the protection offered to him by the RUC in an effort to remain impartial to people who may be involved. However, when he uncovers a conspiracy to destabilize the previous Labour government, he is faced with the consequences of disclosing the information. Ken Loach based his film on the Stalker affair - the real life case of senior police official John Stalker, assigned to investigate a killing by British security officials. Stalker was removed from the case amidst speculations that the then Thatcher government was unhappy with his findings. Screenplay by Jim Allen.

results.title: Calle 54
results.creator_credit: Fernando Trueba, Cristina Huete, Fabienne Servan-Schreiber, Cineteve, Fandango, Fernando Trueba P.C. and Tequila Gang
results.brief_description: Director Fernando Trueba (Belle Epoque) displays his love of Latin jazz in this documentary that showcases the talents of numerous musicians by inviting them to perform in a New York City studio. Preceding each performance is a brief introduction by Trueba addressing the artists’ diverse backgrounds. Aside from these moments however, “Calle 54” fails to expand upon the potentially interesting stories behind the talent, resulting in what is essentially a performance piece celebrating Latin jazz and all its variations. Highlights include Chano Dominguez displaying his flair for merging flamenco and jazz; Cuban pianist Chucho Valdes (son of Bebe) playing a powerful solo; legendary percussionist Tito Puente and horn player Paquito D’Rivera in full swing; barefoot Brazilian Eliane Elias on piano; and the New York-based Jerry Gonzalez wigging out. Other musicians featured are Gato Barbieri, Cachao, Michel Camilo, Eliane Elias, Chico O’Farrill, Orlando ‘Puntilla’ Rios and Carlos ‘Patato’ Valdes. Also features some thrilling flamenco dancing and singing.

results.title: XXX
results.creator_credit: Rob Cohen, Neil H Neil H. Moritz and Revolution Studios
results.brief_description: Director Rob Cohen’s second outing with action star Vin Diesel (their first collaboration was the very successful The Fast and the furious) is a playful hybrid of the James Bond spy movies and extreme sports action. Diesel stars as adrenaline junky Xander Cage who is coerced by the US government into infiltrating a Russian crime ring based in the Czech republic that is planning, amongst other things, the destruction of the world. XXX makes no secret of its Bond appropriations. Cohen gleefully includes in the mix an evil genius based in an elaborate (and not very conspicuous) mountain lair, a beautiful but dangerous woman (Asia Argento), Russian bad guys (yes they’re still bad, irregardless of the Cold War being over), state of the art gizmos and plenty of explosions. It even alludes to the beginnings of a long standing franchise. Cast includes: Samuel L. Jackson, Marton Csokas.

results.title: Pollock
results.creator_credit: Ed Harris, Fred Berner, James Francis Trezza, John Kilik, Brant-Allen, Fred Berner Films, Pollock Films and Zeke Productions
results.brief_description: Directed by Ed Harris, “Pollock” is a biography of the famed abstract expressionist artist, Jackson Pollock. In 1949 Life Magazine had asked the question of whether Pollock was the greatest living painter in the United States? This film replies to the question by showing that in many ways it was the foisting of exactly such demands on Pollock that contributed to his psychological distress and to his eventual death through alcoholism when he was only forty-four. The film aptly documents both Pollock’s frenzied artistic activity as well as his turbulent emotional life. It also effectively conveys the world of the Manhattan art scene in the mid-twentieth century, at the point where New York City was the most artistically exciting city in the world. Though the necessity of the biography genre requires the narrative to undertake certain conventional tropes - struggle, early success, alcoholism, disillusionment and death - the fierce commitment of director Harris to his subject results in a film that arguably does justice to Pollock’s immense, fiery talents. Unsurprisingly, Harris has drawn terrific performances from his cast, including a powerful Marcia Gay Harden as the art critic and life-long friend of the artist, Lee Krasner. In the central role, Ed Harris is passionate and convincing as Pollock. Harden won an Academy Award for her performance in the film. The interview with Harris in the DVD special features menu gives a viewer an excellent understanding of the commitment of the director in making this film.

results.title: Siam sunset
results.creator_credit: John Polson, Al Clark, Artist Services, Film Finance Corporation Australia, New South Wales Film and Television Office and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: After his wife is killed in a freak accident involving a falling refrigerator, British industrial chemist Perry (Linus Roache) travels to Australia to escape and in search of an elusive paint colour after seeing a photo of the Australian outback in a travel brochure. He joins the budget price Whippet tour bus, a motley crew of travellers that includes an aspiring country and western singer, bickering couples, and a woman (Danielle Cormack) fleeing her violent, drug dealing boyfriend whose money she has stolen. Disaster follows Perry everywhere and Australia is no exception: earth tremors, a deceased roadside trader, inclement weather, a dangerous ex-boyfriend and New Year’s Eve at a roadhouse in the middle of nowhere after their bus crashes. A humorous coach war between the Whippet driver determined to out drive a competing driver of a swish coach also travelling to Darwin provides a highlight of the film, as is the Australian outback. Cast also includes: Ian Bliss, Roy Billing, Alan Brough, Rebecca Hobbs, Esme Melville.

results.title: Feet first
results.creator_credit: Clyde Bruckman and Harold Lloyd Corporation
results.brief_description: In Harold Lloyd’s second ‘talkie’ he plays a hopelessly inept shoe clerk, determined to improve himself. Masquerading as a millionare he stows away on a cruise ship but gets dumped overboard in a mail sack. A highlight of the film is a high risk scene on the building scaffolding of a skyscraper where our hapless hero unexpectedly finds himself. Cast includes Harold Lloyd, Barbara Kent, Robert McWade and Lillian Leighton.

results.title: Stray dog = Nora Inu
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa, Shojiro Motoki, Shintoho and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: A young detective Murakami (Toshiro Mifune) has his police gun pick-pocketed on a packed bus in Tokyo. Fearing dismissal, Murakami trawls Tokyo’s underbelly encountering a slew of criminals, black market gunrunners and sleazy types in his quest to recover his weapon and halt the murders occurring at the hand of the thief. In Kurosawa’s ninth feature, the pace is languorous, reflecting the oppressive heat of Occupied Tokyo, sapping the resistance of the many characters that pepper the narrative, sweating their way through an excessive heatwave, battling poverty whilst living amid slums and atrocious post-war conditions. Kurosawa presents a fine example of a noir detective movie, exhibiting his technical virtuosity in a series of vignettes as Murakami chases thieves through grimy back alleys, and sleazy dancehalls, as his naivete ebbs away. Gloomy, intense and atmospheric, this film, about an obsessive quest, delineates a loss of innocence for a rookie cop in search of truth where poverty and degradation causes desperation and amorality to thrive in an urban setting. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: The Emperor and the assassin
results.creator_credit: Chen Kaige, Satoru Iseki, Shirley Kao, Beijing Film Studio and New Wave Entertainmnet
results.brief_description: The most expensive film produced in China at its date of production, this historical epic is based on the event of the forced unification of China in the third century. By 221 BC, after centuries of civil war, seven kingdoms were dominant in China. At this time the ruler of the kingdom of Qin, Ying Zheng (Li Xuejian), raised to believe he had an ancestral duty to unify all of China, undertook a brutal conquest to achieve his goal, thus becoming the country’s first emperor. In this interpretation Zheng is aided in his quest by his lover, Lady Zhao (Gong Li), who devises a fake assassination plot to justify an invasion of the neighboring kingdom of Yan, enlisting the help of Yan assassin Jing Ke (Zhang Fengyi) who is trying to give up his bloody past. As the King becomes increasingly ruthless and bloodthirsty, Lady Zhao shifts her political and romantic allegiances to the assassin. Filled with the back-stabbing imperial politics, murderous betrayals, acts of cruelty and bloody mass slaughter usually associated with Shakespearean tragedy, the emotional impact and tension of the complex narrative is at times dwarfed by the elaborately staged, large-scale battle sequences and the visual grandeur of the landscape. Written by Chen Kaige and Wang Peigong. Photography, Zhao Fei, music, Zhao Jiping.

results.title: Fright night
results.creator_credit: Tom Holland, Herb Jaffe and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Charlie Brewster is a teenage horror buff who becomes engrossed in the mysterious goings on at the spooky house next door, especially when people are reported as missing, who later turn up decapitated. As well as facing the troubles with his girlfriend, Brewster has difficulty convincing anyone (including the police and his mother) of the wicked deeds being committed. Instead he enlists the help of television horror personality Peter Vincent (Roddy McDowall), a horror actor who has fallen on hard times. Together Brewster and Vincent must combat the dreadful evil of Dandridge (Chris Sarandon) and Billy Cole (Jonathan Stark), his menacing assistant. Director Tom Holland (Child’s play) ably blends comedy with suspense in a vampire thriller that makes good use of 1980s special effects and the exuberance of his cast, especially William Ragsdale as the harried teen.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tom Holland, Herb Jaffe and Columbia Pictures
